2016 â€“ Forced Offline by GDPR The website was taken down due to legal uncertainties around thousands of archived patient communications.
2011 â€“ Literary Recognition In her book `The Shaking Woman`, Siri Hustvedt reflects on how the website's aura reports opened new perspectives â€“ including the story of Carl von LinnÃ©, who once saw his own double. The book was surprisingly first published in German.

Over 400 posts offered new perspectives on migraine â€“ until he left academia to start his company.
2009 â€“ Migraine Art: From Section to Book With material jointly compiled by Derek Robinson and Dr. Klaus Podoll â€“ and discovered through the website â€“ a publisher brings the â€˜Migraine Artâ€™ collection to life as a powerful document of lived aura experience.
2006 â€“ A New Look for the Website Complete redesign with CMS and bilingual structure â€“ funded through prize money and private investment.
2005 â€“ Award-Worthy Awareness Nominated for the International Media Award for Science and Art.
2004 â€“ Foundation Established The Migraine Aura Foundation is born â€“ with a growing network, guestbook, and the â€˜Migraine Artâ€™ section.
11/2000 â€“ Patient Forum Goes Live First interactive online platform with forum, guestbook, and physician access â€“ for patients and professionals alike.
08/2000 â€“ Media Spotlight DIE WELT publishes: â€˜How ghost images appear in the brainâ€™. Many patients respond with personal letters.
03/2000 â€“ A Letter from Oliver Sacks Following a scientific publication, a personal letter from Oliver Sacks praises the theoretical work â€“ a rare accolade from the field.
1998 â€“ Understanding Aura â€“ From Theory Alone As a theoretical physicist and not a migraine sufferer himself, Markus Dahlem creates the first computer simulation of migraine aura â€“ based solely on assumptions about the brainâ€™s neural architecture.

data.beyond-the-typical-visual-zigzags#Beyond:
Beyond the Typical Visual Zigzags Migraine aura isnâ€™t only visual â€” for some it is, but many experience effects on speech, sensation, or thinking.
Migraine aura isnâ€™t always temporary â€” conditions like visual snow syndrome can persist well beyond the typical episode.
Migraine aura isnâ€™t always followed by a headache â€” sometimes, the aura stands alone.

data:
While migraine is typically diagnosed through clinical history and the exclusion of other serious causes, the Migraine Aura Foundation highlights the unique diagnostic challenges posed by migraine aura. No blood test, imaging, or procedure can definitively confirm migraineâ€”though such tools may help rule out other conditions. The key remains in gathering a detailed history, supported by structured screening tools.
We advocate for refining this process, especially for aura, where early and accurate recognition possible with the help of digital biomarkers could transform both diagnosis and care.
